repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Calling push_back in a loop to grow the vector caused it to perform repeated unnecessary memory allocations.

In this change, the necessary memory is reserved once ahead of the loop. This has a significant performance improvement for large data sets.

For objects which do not have a length, the original behaviour is preserved.

comment_data.body:
`-1` indicates an exception.
```suggestion
    cdef Py_ssize_t s = PyObject_LengthHint(o, 0)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,12 +40,22 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
         void push_back(T&) except +
+        void reserve(size_t) except +
+
+    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval)
 
 @cname("{{cname}}")
 cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+
     cdef vector[X] v
+    cdef Py_ssize_t s = PyObject_LengthHint(o, -1)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval) except -1
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,12 +40,22 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
         void push_back(T&) except +
+        void reserve(size_t) except +
+
+    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval)

@@ -40,12 +40,22 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
         void push_back(T&) except +
+        void reserve(size_t) except +
+
+    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval)
 
 @cname("{{cname}}")
 cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+
     cdef vector[X] v
+    cdef Py_ssize_t s = PyObject_LengthHint(o, -1)
+
+    if s > 0:
+        v.reserve(s)

comment_data.body:
I think we do want to keep the `except -1` here.

It's not that it should succeed to `PyObject_LengthHint` throws an exception - it's just that the failure should be tested.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,12 +40,22 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
         void push_back(T&) except +
+        void reserve(size_t) except +
+
+    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval)

comment_data.body: Why shouldn't it succeed? We're just silently getting a hint from an object to improve performance. If getting the hint raises, we fall back and nothing prevents the conversion code from working anyway.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,12 +40,22 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
         void push_back(T&) except +
+        void reserve(size_t) except +
+
+    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval)

comment_data.body: That could be a reasonable choice. In which case the solution is to clear the exception rather than to ignore it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,12 +40,22 @@ cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
         void push_back(T&) except +
+        void reserve(size_t) except +
+
+    cdef Py_ssize_t PyObject_LengthHint(object o, Py_ssize_t defaultval)

commit.message:
Reserve vector memory upfront

Calling push_back in a loop caused it to perform repeated unnecessary memory allocations.

In this change, the necessary memory is reserved once ahead of the loop. This has a significant performance improvement for large data sets.

For objects which do not have a length, the old behaviour is preserved.

Reserve vector memory upfront

Calling push_back in a loop caused it to perform repeated unnecessary memory allocations.

In this change, the necessary memory is reserved once ahead of the loop. This has a significant performance improvement for large data sets.

For objects which do not have a length, the old behaviour is preserved.

commit.message:
Add test_generator_to_vector to cpp_stl_conversion.pyx

Add vector conversion test where PyObject_LengthHint returns -1. Also improve takes_vector function to actually check for the passed value.
